text: I slowly moved my hand toward the short sword at my waist—but the scabbard brushed against the buckle with a faint metallic ‘clang’.
The drunkard whipped his head around, bloodshot eyes locking onto me.
“What the hell do you think you’re doing?!”
His rage flared instantly. He slammed his fist onto the table, sending the spilled liquor flying.
“You dare draw your sword?!”
I instinctively took a step back, hand half-curled around the hilt. The air between us thickened—like the moment before a spark meets powder.
Just as he lunged forward, a sound cut through the air—not wind, but the clear ring of steel.
Alicia was already on her feet. Her cloak swept past the hearth, and a flash of silver lit the room.
No one saw what she did. In the next heartbeat, the drunk was face-down on the floor, his head buried in his own spilled drink.
I stood frozen, staring at her. Only then did I realize—I’d never needed to draw my sword at all.
She withdrew her blade. The firelight shimmered faintly along the cracked edge of the steel.
“You were a step too slow.”
“Looks like you didn’t need any help.”
Alicia lifted her eyes slightly. The firelight flickered in them—half amusement, half something else.
“Maybe.”
She slid the sword back into its sheath, the soft rasp of metal filling the quiet room.
The air moved again; the fire crackled, and a few patrons peeked out before hastily returning to their seats.
“Clean this up. No need to invite the town guards here.”
Her tone carried no command—just calm statement of fact.
“All right.”
I nodded and picked up a rag, wiping away the spilled wine. She stood quietly beside me—waiting, perhaps, or lost in thought.
